text:
MORE ON THAT LOBBYING BAN: The political law experts at Wiley Rein point out President Donald Trump 's lobbying ban exempts “communicating or appearing with regard to” agency rulemaking, adjudication, and licensing proceedings.
Story Continued Below
"Thus, it appears that President   would prohibit 'lobbying activities' by alumni appointees of his administration, even if such activities comprise background, behind-the-scenes activities and fall below the LDA’s registration thresholds," Robert Walker and Eric Wang wrote . "On the other hand, the Obama executive order did not exempt lobbying on agency rulemaking, adjudication, or licensing proceedings."
— Trump's ban probably won't deter lobbyists from joining the administration, Megan Wilson reports for The Hill. “I have talked to a number of people who are seeking advice on whether or not to join the administration, and the ethical obligations have not been a determining factor,” said Ivan Adler, a headhunter at The McCormick Group . 
A MODEST PROPOSAL from The McCormick Group's John Hesse for "outcome tracking for government relations": Lobbyists should disclose all their activity from retainer to result, letting everyone see exactly what they did and what they achieved. And lobbying should be defined broadly to include "any activity that furthers the self-interested public policy goal of a client or person/corporation."
Hesse elaborates: "For example: Exxon retains firm ABC to lobby on Arctic drilling rights. My idea is that firm ABC would have to file upon retainer and throughout the process noting the issue and results achieved. Then finally, firm ABC would have to report on the end result of activity. Did Exxon win or lose? Right now we assume lobbying terminations are failures or successes but we have to guess which one is correct.
"If we knew results publicly, we could measure effectiveness and transparently see exactly how influence works or does not work. We could also tell which firms were effective and then journalists could investigate why. Again we assume because lobbyist are paid they are effective at something but we don’t really know. The public does not know that firm ABC got language inserted into XYZ conference report that benefited Widget company unless someone does a whole lot of research. It should be easier. I think then lobbyists and the public would grow to trust one another over time."
TAKING STOCK: The researchers at Delve size up the fallout from Trump's week of using executive orders as "souped-up press release[s]": "Continuing these run-and-gun tactics with regards to executive action will have serious long-term consequences, which will occur when the president seeks support on the Hill for his nominees and policy agenda," they wrote in their Administration Project newsletter tracking the transition. "Even if key Republicans in Congress are not consulted on the content of executive actions, failing to loop them in prior to the documents’ release leads to poor messaging overall. The President is about to announce a Supreme Court nominee and a litany of other nominations he will need help from Congressional leadership to shepherd through, and this stumble in the relationship between either end of Pennsylvania Avenue could put constraints on that help."
THANKS FOR THE MEMORIES . With this I hang my PI hat. Keep in touch. You know where to find me:   For future PI tips: tmeyer@politico.com .

IRION LANDS : Hogan Lovells hired Mark Irion , the departed president of LEVICK and former CEO of Dutko Worlwide (now Grayling ), to create a new strategic communications service. More and more law and lobbying firms are adding comms practices. Irion will work with the firm's lawyers and add his own staff.
"Our strategic communications initiative is part of our broader effort to ensure we can provide complete solutions to our clients’ problems," CEO Steve Immelt said. "Increasingly, successful strategies for resolving complex matters involve the ability to communicate effectively in the public arena as well as in legal proceedings. In this digital age public perceptions form rapidly and can determine the ultimate outcomes of our clients’ legal strategies, which makes it imperative that we help shape the public narrative in order to achieve a successful outcome.”
DEM DONORS: The Democracy Alliance hired former White House Public Engagement Senior Associate Director Archana Sahgal, signaling the Democratic donor group's commitment to resisting Trump. Sahgal will build out a new information hub, working closely with progressive organizations. She first joined the Obama administration as director of the Office of Advisory Committees and Industry Outreach at the Department of Commerce and previously led significant programs at the Open Society Foundation , the Color of Democracy Fund , and the Civic Engagement Fund for Arab, Middle Eastern, Muslim, and South Asian Communities , which she co-founded and directed.
The Democracy Alliance is focusing on the 2017, 2018 and 2020 elections, and redistricting fights. In March, the DA and the Committee on States will convene a donors, political activists, and strategists to develop a plan to take back power in the states. 
JOBS REPORT: 
— Valero hired Salo Zelermyer from Bracewell to to lead the oil refiner's Washington office as vice president-federal affairs and counsel. Zelermyer previously was senior counsel at the Energy Department under George W. Bush . He succeeds Craig Felner , who is joining a lobbying firm TBA.
— Widmeyer (part of Finn Partners ) hired Heather Foster , an Obama ’08 campaign alumna who went on to work in the White House Office of Engagement, the Education Department and the My Brother’s Keeper initiative.
— Rory Brosius , deputy director of the White House's Joining Forces Initiative for the last four years, will join ScoutComms , a military family-focused communications, advocacy and research firm, as a vice president.
— FleishmanHillard hired Michael Moroney from Story Partners as an account supervisor. Joseph Vara joined as an account executive on the social & influence team after spending the 2016 cycle working at Republican political tech firm Targeted Victory .
— Quicken Loans promoted Chris Berardini to senior vice president for federal government affairs. 
— McDermott Will & Emery hired Mary Strimel as a partner in the antitrust practice group from the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice, where she served as Chief of one of two Antitrust Criminal Enforcement sections. She previously worked in the Antitrust Division’s Networks and Technology Enforcement Section.
— Rob Hawkins left D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser ’s office to join Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough ’s government relations practice. He was the mayor’s deputy chief of staff and special counsel. 
— Robert Cogan , Rep. Diane Black ’s deputy chief of staff, is moving over to the House Budget Committee, where he will be a senior policy adviser on tax and other issues. 
— Steve Gordon , managing partner of Total Spectrum/Steve Gordon and Associates, hired Todd Smith, former chief of staff for then-Rep. Nathan Deal , and Blake Fulenwider, former deputy commissioner of the Georgia Department of Community Health and Healthcare Reform Administrator in Deal’s Office of Planning and Budget as governor. Fulenwider will be Total Spectrum’s Georgia director.
—The Competitive Enterprise Institute hired Jim Harper as vice president from the Cato Institute, working on privacy, cybersecurity, telecommunications, intellectual property, counterterrorism, government transparency and digital currency. He previously was counsel to committees in both chambers of Congress and a founding member of DHS’ Data Privacy and Integrity Advisory Committee.
—Communications and public affairs firm Glen Echo Group promoted Katie Barr to executive vice president and chief operating officer, Ellen Satterwhite to vice president, and Aaron Alberico to director.
— Deloitte named Steve Kimble to lead its tax business, succeeding Carl Allegretti. 
OUTSIDE GROUP: Trump deputy campaign manager David Bossie appears to be off the K Street market (for now) as he joined the pro-Trump nonprofit America First Policies. Other aides bound for the group: Brad Parscale, Trump’s former digital director; former Pence aides Nick Ayers and Marty Obst ; Rick Gates , a close confidant of former campaign chairman Paul Manafort; and spokeswoman Katrina Pierson, Ben Kamisar reports for The Hill. 
— Newt Gingrich and Rudy Giuliani will chair another nonprofit, the Great America Alliance , run by Republican strategists Ed Rollins and Eric Beach, reports POLITICO ’s Alex Isentadt . 
SPOTTED at RENEWPR 's Second Anniversary Celebration at Nopa Kitchen + Bar Monday night: RENEWPR President Ben Finzel and his husband Mark Pimble; Katherine Hamilton of 38 North Solutions; Joe Fuld and Margo Scott Dunn of The Campaign Workshop; David Leiter of ML Strategies; Wolf Trap CEO Arvind Manocha and his husband Gideon Malone; Lisa Jacobson of The Business Council for Sustainable Energy; Kateri Callahan of the Alliance to Save Energy; Sam Adams of WRI; Chris Jones of Politemps; Chris Cimko of Cimko Strategies; Tony Silva of Ogilvy PR; Ron Painter and Yenory Garcia-Pouncil of the National Association of Workforce Boards; Tiffany Shackelford and Elena Waskey of NGA; Chris McCannel of Eris Group; Jim Owen of EEI; Margaret Dunning of Finn Partners; Christina Saull of Finn Partners and her husband Bradley Saull of Professional Services Council; Ann Davison of PWC; David Olive of Catalyst Partners; Deborah Sauri of iSpy Creative and her husband Michael Sauri of TriVista USA; Anne Banner of GW School of Medicine and Health Sciences; Joe Sangirardi and Courtney Mott of the Victory Fund; Matt Thorn of OutServe-SLDN; USA Today contributor Bill Loveless; Michael Lustig of SNL Energy; Louis Labrecque of Bloomberg BNA; Taylor Gross of The Herald Group; Mike Schmitt of Crosscut Strategies; PR impresarios Jayne Brady and Betsy Mullins; super lobbyists Richard Goodstein, Andy Athy and many more.
